Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reproducing Difference in Biomedicine: The Case of Sex as a Biological Variable

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines how biological differences are reproduced through the regulation of inclusion in biomedicine by considering how sex is reproduced as binary, biological, and distinct from gender at an institutional level. It does so by examining the emergence of a new policy mandate of the US National Institutes of Health. Called 'Sex as a Biological Variable,' these policies require the inclusion of equal numbers of male and female cells and animals in all pre-clinical research funded by the NIH. While scholars have shown that the production of biological knowledge is shaped by the assumptions of scientific researchers, far less is known about the role of government agencies and regulatory processes in reproducing certain forms of biological difference. Using archival data and other textual materials, as well as interviews with stakeholders, this project examines the processes by which the NIH developed policies mandating the examination of sex differences in basic and pre-clinical research. The overall aim is to show how particular accounts of sex and gender become institutionalized through regulation and rule-making.

This is a multi-method investigation into the ways in which embodied difference, knowledge, institutions, and rule-making serve to produce sex and gender as distinct categories of personhood. The specific case study underlying this investigation is a new policy mandate at the US National Institutes of Health that requires the inclusion of equal numbers of male and female cells and animals in all pre-clinical research funded by the NIH. The project synthesizes data from archives, public policy documents, and interviews with stakeholders to understand how biological difference comes to be constructed as an object of scientific and medical inquiry that is knowable by certain experts who are granted legitimacy as knowledge-producers, while other accounts are denied institutional support. In doing so it advances literature in science and technology studies on the intersection of gender roles and regulatory interventions and on the influence of gender ideology on the work of scientific researchers and medical practitioners. Overall, the project seeks to explain how certain forms of difference come to be presumed biological and privileged as such within research policy and to examine how actors and organizations located outside of the NIH influence or attempt to influence such policies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated how the National Institutes of Health (NIH) in the United States (U.S.) came to introduce a policy mandating attention to sex in basic and preclinical research. Called Sex as a Biological Variable (SABV), the policy announced in 2014 and implemented in 2016 requires researchers using animal models to include both sexes and disaggregate their findings by sex, in order to support investigation of sex differences in disease and drug response. Researchers using cell lines are also encouraged to identify the sex of their research materials, where possible, and consider how sex may be relevant to their findings. Advocates of the SABV policy consider it a victory for the larger project of making biomedical research in the U.S. more inclusive of and attentive to the specific experiences of women. However, critics believe it simplifies as a form of embodied difference that influences human health and illness, by failing to account for the considerable overlap between women and men and the complex ways that “biological” sex interacts with gender and other “social” health determinants.

This qualitative project drew on semi-structured interviews, NIH meeting minutes, and textual materials in order to investigate debates surrounding the SABV policy with the goal of understanding: (1) how the policy came about; (2) how and why various stakeholders have either supported or resisted the policy; and (3) the implications of the policy for both scientific and public understandings of what “sex” is, how it occurs in the human (and non-human) body, and how it relates to health and illness. With the support of the award, a total of 42 interviews with policymakers and biomedical researchers were conducted and transcribed, including eight interviews conducted in person at the Organization for the Study of Sex Differences annual meeting in 2019. A body of textual data comprised of NIH meeting minutes from 1996-2018, 210 responses to a 2015 NIH Request for Information, and 62 published editorials and policy debates was also collected and analyzed during the award period.

Research findings have subsequently been presented at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Association, the Society for Social Studies of Science, Sociologists for Women in Society, and Neurogenderings.

There are currently three papers under peer review or in development that draw on data collected and analyzed with the support of the award and which comprised the dissertation. The first, currently under review, seeks to contribute to Science and Technology Studies (STS) scholarship by investigating how “sex” is not a singular, clearly defined concept, but rather one that takes multiple, sometimes contradictory forms in the policy work and advocacy surrounding the SABV policy. The second paper takes up the reproducibility crisis facing preclinical research and investigates the relationships between animal research, ideas about human health and disease, and concepts of biological sex. The third paper, now a collaboration with a neuroscientist, considers the promises and limitations of the precision medicine paradigm as applied to sex differences research. Additionally, a book manuscript is under development with the goal of publishing it as part of a university press series focused on STS. 

Taken together, the project has supported interdisciplinary dialogue and exchange and is now informing the researcher’s efforts to engage policymakers in the U.S. and Canada in discussions about the strengths and limitations of the SABV policy. A discussion piece aimed at informing how social scientists and STS scholars can engage policymakers in discussions about the complexities of biological sex was recently submitted to the forum section of a feminist science studies journal. Finally, findings were also presented to the International Olympic Committee as part of their efforts to consult social scientists concerning the complexities of biological sex as it applies to the regulation of inclusion in elite sport.
